last on this: this is about the movement that gained popularity in 20th century europe, when the term minimalism was created - an idea that pushes towards homogeneity. there are some cultures that look more minimalist than others but theres still cultural identity within them

the more i learn about high fashion, the less i want to own it tbh.
@01000011___ i hadnt seen that video. i deleted the tweet suggesting her account, people were just replying with that main video of hers so i figured she was fine.

@thierrymulger
@01000011___ weve discussed this in some of my classes at uni. one girl has recently started talking about it on tik tok, but from the videos ive seen she provides sources.
the idea that you have to be a consumer of luxury fashion in order to have valid criticism for or against it is a very capitalist mindset. being an art collector doesnt make you an art critic.
@tabibutts back in business baby!!!
@michofthestars shes right !!!!!!

@kl_auner efficiency without emotion or identity doesnt seem so efficient.
@yvessaintangel shes so right
this extends even further than minimalism as an aesthetic. minimalism as a lifestyle and the idea of only keeping what counts almost always excludes any form of ornamentation.

adolf loos, austrian architect early proponent of minimalism, described ornamentation as something thats barbaric criminal. international style/ the modern architecture of 20s-30s was intentionally designed for western comfortability.
right like lets talk about how minimalism started as a form of cultural erasure. https://t.co/20l7V5mI5x
